Laboratory of Thin Film and Microfabrication Technology (Ministry of Education), Shanghai Jiao Tong University Shanghai 200240 PR China Sulfur-containing gaseous contaminant treatment is a key issue in the healthy and sustainable development of industry, especially SO2 and H2S occur with natural gas extraction and fossil fuel burning. Traditionally, the commercial method for H2S or SO2 requires numerous desiccants and enormous energy consumption. Encouragingly, electrochemical coupling system, which provide an efficient, sustainable, and economic pathway for sulfur-containing gaseous contaminants removal, can convert H2S and SO2 to recyclable substance in a moderate environment and simultaneously transfer the energy contained in them to other more valuable product. The current review discusses the mechanism and principle of the electrochemical coupling system as well as the recent studies on the electrochemical removal of H2S and SO2, with the goal of providing a suitable idea to solve the problems of energy waste and resource recovery in pollutants treatment. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Electrochemical coupling system Sulfur-containing gaseous waste Contaminants removal Resource recovery Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction The industrialization of human society has inevitably resulted in a series of environmental issues, the most serious of which is air pollution, which threatens subsistence of all species living on the planet [1,2]. As one of the most widespread air pollutants, sulfur-containing gaseous contaminants definitely do serious harm to environment and have been restricting eco-friendly growth of industry, especially the sulfur dioxide (SO2) gas from fossil fuel burning and the hydrogen sulfide (H2S) gas from natural gas extraction, which are both directly related to energy [3–6]. Acid rain formed by SO2 is not only corrosive to metals, but also causes damage to the soil environment and ecological balance, besides, SO2 can attack the respiratory tract and cause cancer and cardiovascular disease [7,8]. However, H2S exhibits strong toxicity at low concentrations (50 ppm) and becomes lethal at 6–14 times higher concentrations, which shows the obvious impact on the nervous system of human [3,4]. Seeking efficient approaches to eliminate the pollutants has become a key issue of global concern and many efforts have been made to decompose the pollutants and clean the environment. Traditionally, sulfur-containing gaseous contaminants are separated and removed after adsorption and oxidization process. For instance, methyl diethanolamine (MDEA) is the mainstream H2S desiccant in natural gas purification process with excellent selectivity and stability [9–11] and advanced wet scrubber such as limestone forced oxidation (LSFO) is qualified for excess 95 % SO2 removal with limestone [12,13]. It’s worth noting that H2S and SO2 are potentially valuable chemicals rich in energy. For example, H2S is rich in elemental H and S, while SO2 prefers to be oxidized to SO4 2- and releases large energy. However, for the above technique, MDEA+Clause process can only contribute to the recovery of elemental sulfur with all hydrogen converted to H2O and must operate at high temperature up to 1000–1200 ℃ [14,15]. In case of SO2, LSFO sacrifices thermal energy released from SO2 oxidization (ΔG0 =−361.25 kJ mol−1) with the extra consumption of enormous limestones [12,13]. Therefore, there are a series of resource and energy consumption problems with traditional methods for the treatment of sulfur-containing gases, like SO2 and H2S. In view of this, a new environmental-friendly and efficient method that can both eliminates the pollutants and simultaneously fully recovers the valuable resource stored in them is considered as a promising way to address the environmental pollution problem as well as the energy crisis. In this review, we will introduce sulfur-containing gaseous contaminant treatment through electrochemical (EC) and photoelectrochemical (PEC) techniques, which especially focus on the integrated system coupling anodic reaction with cathodic reaction to remove other pollutants and simultaneously recover resource efficiently. The coupling system realizes the goal of H2S splitting entirely at normal temperature and combines reduction reaction of H+, O2 and CO2 with the innovation of cathodic electrode. The similar mechanism works on SO2 removal to obtain energy and resource from the coupling system. Former coupling system techniques can have a significant impact on the revolution of technique for sulfur-containing gaseous contaminant treatment. A relevant technique mechanism and a series of cutting-edge studies on sulfur-containing gaseous contaminants removal via catalysis will be exhibited. 2 Principle and mechanism The principle of the electrochemical coupling system is based on the transfer of matter and energy, and realizes the cooperative treatment and resource recovery of H2S and SO2 through the coupling of anodic oxidation and cathodic reduction reaction. Due to the oxidative decomposition of H2S and SO2, the coupling reaction process can be realized by controlling the reduction reaction of H+ with different substances. The anodic and cathodic reactions can be simply summarized into the following reaction formulas (1−3). (1) Anodic reaction: A – e - → B + H+ (2) Cathodic reaction: C + H+ + e - → D (3) Total reaction: A + C → B + D For instance, A can be H2S or SO2, while B is its corresponding oxidation product, such as S or SO4 2-; C is a cathodic reduction substance, such as H+, O2 or CO2, while D is its corresponding cathodic product, such as H2, H2O2, or CO [16–21]. This process of coupling different oxidation and reduction reactions makes great use of the energy contained in H2S and SO2, which significantly reduces the total reaction energy and improves the energy efficiency of electrocatalysis. Three coupling reactions for H2S splitting [16–18] can assistant in reducing relative reaction energy, whose ΔG0 (Gibbs Free Energy) decrease 204.17 kJ mol−1, 204.17 kJ mol−1, and 441.41 kJ mol−1, which result from “Eq.5–Eq.4″, “Eq.8–Eq.7″, “Eq.12–Eq.10″, respectively. And three coupling reactions for SO2 removal [19–21] can also reduce relative reaction energy consumption, whose ΔG0 all decrease 361.25 kJ mol−1, which results from “Eq.6–Eq.4″, “Eq.9–Eq.7″, “Eq.13–Eq.11″, respectively. And the lower ΔG0 results from more energy released by SO2 oxidization. Therefore, the electrochemical coupling catalysis of H2S and SO2 not only removes pollutants, but also reduces energy consumption and strengthens the generation of valuable products. H2 generation: (4) H2O (l) → H2 (g) + 1/2 O2 (g) ΔG0=237·19 kJ mol−1 Coupling system for H2 generation: (5) H2S (g) → H2 (g) + S (s) ΔG0=33·02 kJ mol−1 (6) SO2(g) + 2OH- → SO4 2-+ H2(g) ΔG0=−124·06 kJ mol−1 H2O2 evolution: (7) H2O (l) + 1/2 O2 (g)→ H2O2 (l) ΔG0=119·08 kJ mol−1 Coupling system for H2O2 evolution: (8) H2S (g) + O2 (g) → H2O2 (l) + S (s) ΔG0=−85·09 kJ mol−1 (9) SO2 (g)+ O2(g)+2OH- →H2O2 (l)+ SO4 2- ΔG0=−242·17 kJ mol−1 CO2 reduction: (10) H2O (l) + CO2 (g)→ CO (g)+ H2 (g)+ O2 (g) ΔG0=494·31 kJ mol−1 (11) OH- + CO2 (g)→ HCOO- + O2 (g) ΔG0=218·47 kJ mol−1 Coupling system for CO2 reduction: (12) H2S (g) + CO2 (g) → CO(g) + S (s) + H2O (l) ΔG0=52·9 kJ mol−1 (13) CO2 (g) + SO2 (g) +3OH-→ HCOO-+ SO4 2- +H2O (l) ΔG0=−142·78 kJ mol−1 In order to realize the coupling catalytic system, it is usually necessary to build a two-chamber electrochemical reactor (H-Cell) as shown in Fig. 1. The anode and the cathode are placed in the anode chamber and the cathode chamber respectively, and the middle is separated by a proton membrane [22,23]. H2S or SO2 passes into the anode chamber for reaction, and the resulting protons can be transferred to the cathode for reaction. Through the control of potential and molecular types, the products of anode and cathode can be regulated. According to the catalytic mechanism, the anode is usually a carbon electrode with high conductivity, such as graphite [24,25], while the cathode can be a hydrogen production electrode, a hydrogen peroxide electrode or a CO2 reduction electrode to yield varieties of products by corresponding coupling system. Electrocatalytic energy usually depends on Direct Current (DC) power, but direct power supply through solar cells can also provide a greener and more economical way [26,27]. In comparison to electrocatalysis, the photoelectrocatalytic (PEC) technique has received wide attention in the past years because it offers a way of high-adaptable, low-cost, fast and deep treatment of environmental pollutants using the most clean, abundant and renewable solar energy [28–30]. The PEC cell is usually established using a semiconductor based photoanode where oxidation reactions occur. The majority of the pollutant can be oxidized and eliminated in the anode during such a photoelectrocatalytic process. Similar to the EC cell, the PEC cell is also composed of two chambers, with the photoanode and cathode placed in the anode chamber and cathode chamber respectively. Different from the principle of electrocatalysis, photoelectrocatalysis is mainly based on the oxidation and decomposition of pollutants driven by holes generated by photoanode, so its principle can be summarized as follows: (14) Anodic reaction: photoanode + hv → e - + h + (15) A1 + h + – e - → B1 + H+ (16) Cathodic reaction: C1 + H+ + e - → D1 (17) Total reaction: A1 + C1 → B1 + D1 According to the principle of photoelectrocatalysis, light-to-electricity conversion efficiency of the photoanode primarily decides catalytic efficiency of the PEC system. Considering comprehensive properties of semiconductor materials, WO3, TiO2, Fe2O3, BiVO4, etc., [29,30] and their composites are commonly used as fundamental materials for photoanode preparation. As for the cathode, when the cathode is an electrocatalytic reaction, it is the same as the electrocatalytic system. However, for PEC cells, photocathode is another possibility. It is usually composed of p-type semiconductors, on which reduction reactions, such as hydrogen production, can take place under light. Therefore, if the PEC system consists of photoanodes and photocathodes, we can call it a dual-illumination photoelectrochemical cell, which is a more efficient system for the use of solar energy. In addition, the modified system can only be driven by solar energy and no longer relies on an external power supply, so it is a better green electrochemical system. 3 Electrochemical coupling system for the H2S purification Based on the above principles and the electrochemical coupling system, researchers have focused on the resource utilization of H2S. On the other hand, direct electrocatalysis or photocatalysis of H2S will result in deposition of elemental sulfur on the electrode, which will subsequently be passivated, or S2-peroxidation to Sx 2- by free radicals (PEC), making recovery and separation difficult [31–33]. As a result, Zong et al. proposed that anodic reactions incorporate the I- /I3 - cyclic redox system [34]. On the anode surface, iodide (I-) is oxidized to triiodide (I3 -) (3I- → I3 - +2e- E0 =0.54 V). H2S is oxidized to S by the produced I3 - (E0 (S/H2S) = 0.142 V vs. NHE). As a result, I3 - is reduced to I- for the next cycle. As a result, H2S could be constantly converted to S. Similar strategies can be utilized for the conversion of S2 to elemental sulfur in a moderate environment with Fe2+-EDTA/Fe3+-EDTA. Using the aforementioned H2S oxidation mechanism, a coupling system for H2S removal can be established with simultaneous H2 evolution, H2O2 generation, or CO2 reduction by changing the cathodic reaction, resulting in maximum resource utilization and multiple pollutant removal. 3.1 Simultaneous H2 generation and S recovery In order to solve the problem that Clause process can only recover elemental sulfur from H2S, the first strategy of an electrochemical coupling system is constructed by the combination of S recovery and H2 evolution from H2S splitting. This system can be operated in a moderate environment and recover green and clean H2, which can actually effectively mitigate global greenhouse effect caused by fossil fuel burning [35] and dramatically-increasing demand for H2 [36]. Besides, with direct utilization of the hydrogen contained in H2S, the coupling system may achieve a state of almost no waste. Therefore, Zong et al. (2014) [34] primarily reported the coupling system for S recovery and H2 evolution, among which TiO2/Ti/n+p-Si was utilized as the photoanode and Pt was utilized as the cathode therein. TiO2/Ti/n+p-Si could obtain approximately 30 mA cm−2 photocurrent, whose IPCE (incident photon to current efficiency) was around 47 % [38–41]. The photoelectric two-chamber coupling system was completed after I- or I3 - was introduced into the anodic chamber ( Fig. 2a). Under light illumination, the h+ generated by the TiO2/Ti/n + p-Si electrode oxidized I- to I3 -; then, I3 - oxidized S2- to S and was reduced to I-; and so on. Simultaneously, generated H+ is transfered through the nafion membrane to the cathode to achieve equilibrium for H2 generation. The saturation photocurrent of 24 mA cm−2 could be stable for 180 min for 8.3 mL of H2 gas generation [34]. Another experiment demonstrated that H2S splitting was unsuccessful without these loops because of low solubility of H2S in acidic solution [34]. The coupling system unquestionably possesses greater environmental resilience. Considering further improving the solar-to-chemical efficiency, our group [16] proposed a dual-photoelectrode solar-driven coupling system for H2 evolution and S recovery, which was constructed by a WO3 photoanode and Si/PVC photocathode (Fig. 2b). The key idea was the self-bias function between the WO3 photoanode and Si/PVC photocathode due to their mismatched Fermi levels. When the coupling system stayed in an operating state, holes generated from Si/PVC and electrons generated from WO3 could be linked by an external circuit and an internal bias [16]. WO3 photoanodes with nano-array structures show higher photoelectrocatalytic performance because of their better charge transfer performance than particle composite films and higher specific surface area than dense thin films. At present, the main methods used to prepare nanoarray WO3 photoanodes are the hydrothermal method, vapor deposition, magnetron sputtering, anodization, and so on [42–48]. Although these methods can prepare ordered nanoarray WO3 photoanodes, they are not suitable for large-scale preparation. In this study, WO3 photoanodes with nanoarray structures were prepared by controlled reduction of peroxotungstic acid and have highly active (002) surfaces with preferential exposure. The thickness of the film is about 850 nm, the average thickness of the nanosheet is about 100 nm, and its IPCE to 400 nm light is 51 %[49]. Using this high performance WO3 photoanode, dual photoelectrodes coupling system could be completely self-driven and obtain high recovery rates of ∼1.04 mg h−1 cm−2 S and ∼0.75 mg h−1 cm−2 H2. The coupling system was shown in Fig. 2b running continuously for 5 h, and the addition of H2S only briefly affected the photocurrent with S generation, indicating a more efficient H2S splitting through the I3 -/I- loop [16]. Subsequently, the solar energy efficiency of the coupling system was further improved by the addition of solar cells. Ma et al. (2020) [37] designed a novel device named solar redox flow batteries (SRFBs), which was essentially the integration of the solar cell and the electrochemical coupling system. For SRFBs, the idea of H2S removal was transformed into the decomposition of H2S for energy storage. With Fe3+/Fe2+ and H+ as the energy carrier (Fig. 2c), SRFBs with H2S splitting efficiency greater than 15.2 % outperform solar-to-chemical energy conversion efficiency. Simultaneously, the current density could keep 40 mA cm−2 after 100 cycles and H2 production rate could reach 5.77 mmol h−1 [37]. Besides, a recent study showed monoethanolamine (MEA) as the absorbent for H2S to build a coupling system for H2S electrolysis to solve problem of S attaching to anode, because MEA could increase S solubility and be the bond for the coupling system at the same time [50]. The ability to replace water with organic solvents resulted in the electrode of the coupling system performing significantly better, but there exist lots of unsolved troubles of organic solvents being used as electrolytes, recycling and secondary pollution of organic solvents would constrain wide application. 3.2 Simultaneous H2O2 generation and S recovery Compared to H2 evolution in a cathodic chamber, from the point of view of thermodynamics, the combination of S production from H2S and hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) formation is a spontaneous process and is easier to realize (Eqs.5,8). Of importance, H2O2 is a widely used green water treatment agent and an important chemical raw material [51–53]. To date, the traditional anthraquinone method is used for H2O2 production, but this process is complex and require explosive hydrogen gas [54]. As a result, combining H2O2 preparation and S recovery from H2S treatment can not only achieve full-resource H2S treatment but also significantly reduce energy consumption. Zong et al. [18] first reported an integrated redox coupling system by photoelectrochemical technique without external bias to synthesize H2O2 and split H2S to S ( Fig. 3a) [18]. In addition to the arrangement of the I-/I3 - ion loop in the anodic chamber, the anthraquinone/anthrahydroquinone (AQ/H2AQ) loop was ingeniously introduced in the cathodic chamber and responsible for the conduction of electrons between the cathode and the O2-H2O2 reaction. After electrons traveled through an external circuit to the cathode, they could utilize H+ transferred from the anodic reaction to reduce AQ to H2AQ, then the obtained H2AQ could reduce O2 to H2O2 at a further step while H2AQ became AQ again (Fig. 3a). By which the selectivity for H2O2 generation is steadily promoted. Subsequently, the group found that AQ was more efficiently reduced in the carbon electrode than in the Pt electrode, so the coupling system with TiO2/Ti/n+p-Si as the anode and carbon as the cathode was completed. Finally, the coupling system achieved 1.1 % overall efficiency and yields of around 70 μmol h−1 H2O2 yields. For further improvement of solar energy efficiency and faradaic efficiency of H2O2 generation, our group [55] proposed a series-wound WO3/SiPVC photoanode and gas diffusion cathode coupling system for H2S splitting and H2O2 generation (Fig. 3b). WO3 nano-flake arrays were synthesized by hydrothermal process and placed at the front of SiPVC to form a series-wound photoanode. Among which the transmission of sunlight by WO3 was basically same as the absorption of sunlight by SiPVC, so the series-wound electrode could improve the adsorption of sunlight to ensure photocurrent promotion and the coupling system completely self-driven without extra power supply. Due to their high catalytic efficiency and reliable electrochemical performance, carbonaceous materials are the ideal option for producing H2O2 [56–61]. Because of its numerous defect active sites, viable O2 mass transfer channel, positive zeta potential, and substantial BET surface area, mesoporous carbon in particular displays higher H2O2 production performance [62]. The study has shown that, due to the excellent hydrophobicity of polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE), its modification on the surface of carbon materials can significantly enhance the diffusion and adsorption enrichment of O2. In this work, the Nickel foam with abundant microporous structure and high specific surface area was utilized to synthesize GDE by the modified substrate layer made of Polytetrafluoroethylen (PTFE) and graphite. Synthesized GDE could effectively help O2 rapidly diffuse to the functional region of cathode to promote the selectivity of H2O2 generation, whose faradaic efficiency is 13 times higher than that operates by carbon felt cathode (Fig. 3b). Finally, the zero-bias coupling system maintained a 14 mA current for a long term run and produced 0.08 mmol h−1 H2O2 production rate (Fig. 3b) [55]. 3.3 Simultaneous CO generation and S recovery The coupling system for CO generation and S recovery is an environmentally friendly and resource-saving method to remove green-house gas and toxic H2S and recover valuable CO and S. Because he coupling system dissolves approximately 20 % of the CO2 and H2S contained in raw natural gas [63–65], it is a useful tool for natural gas purification [17,66]. Besides, CO recovered is a stable and combustible energy resource that does not need to be further separated from natural gas, and solid-state S generated is easily separated. Therefore, Ma et al.[17] prospectively proposed the scheme of combining CO2 reduction H2S splitting to recover valuable CO and elemental S ( Fig. 4a), which focused on the issue that CO2 and H2S are generally concomitant with each other in natural gas extraction [17]. In anodic chamber, EDTA-Fe3+/EDTA-Fe2+ loop steadily controlled H2S splitting to prevent the generation of Polysulfide product. Although the mechanism of EDTA-Fe3+/EDTA-Fe2+ loop was as same as Fe3+/Fe2+ loop, EDTA-Fe3+/EDTA-Fe2+ was more 182 times difficult to across the membrane than general Fe3+/Fe2+ to ensure that cathodic reaction was not disturbed. In cathodic chamber, graphite oxide (GO) with a greyish appearance after ultrasonic treatment was added into the Zn(CH3COO)2 solution to synthesize the ZnO@G electrode for improving CO2-to-CO reaction selectivity and coupling system electroconductivity. Finally, with the graphite-made ZnO@G cathode and graphite anode, the current density of the coupling system increased to 8.5 mA cm−2 and a CO production rate of approximately 0.13 mmol h−1 cm−2 was obtained in long-term stable operation. Referring to above, Zhang et al. [66] designed an economic and efficient electrochemical coupling system for synergistical treatment of CO2 and H2S to recover CO and S (Fig. 4b), which possessed nearly 7-fold CO production rate and 5-fold current density than that of mentioned research [17]. Herein, the ultrathin dual flow cell design significantly improved the flow and circulation of gases and solutions, especially the distance between anode and cathode, which was considerably shortened to reduce the internal resistance of reactor (Fig. 4b). Currently, both noble metal-based catalysts such as gold, silver, and palladium [67,68] and non-noble metal-based catalysts such as zinc and copper [69–74] are the subject of extensive research. Comparatively, molecular catalysts such as cobalt phthalocyanine (CoPc) have been utilized in the electrocatalytic evolution of hydrogen and synthesis of several organic substances [75–77], and it featured distinct active centers and a structure that was simple to operate [78]. Thus, in cathodic chamber, the prepared CoPc was deposited on GDE made of graphite and polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) by spray-coating and then suffering hydrophobic treatment by Airbrush. The combination of the high-selectivity CoPc for CO2-to-CO and the hydrophobic GDE maked CO2 favorably diffused to reaction area and efficiently converted to CO. Ultimately, the designed coupling system constructed by novel flow cell and gas diffusion electrode (GDE) possessed more than 72.41 % energy efficiency and 24.94 mg cm−2 h−1 S and 19.93 mL cm−2 h−1 CO production (Fig. 4b) [66], which was extremely expected to be applied in practice. Energy efficiency and economy are the key factors that determine whether a system can be widely promoted. Subsequently, we utilized an economic model[79,80] to simulate the actual operation of the coupling system and explain profitability at a long-term run. At optimal external voltage and general solar power price, about 0.02 $ was obtained for per cubic meter natural gas has been treated [66]. After calculation, this coupling system can save around 0.03 $ for per cubic meter natural gas compared to a series of traditional process[81–83]. In Comparison to the conventional methods, the proposed electrochemical method shows obvious lower operation cost in terms of solar electricity price and carbon tax. 4 Electrochemical coupling system for the SO2 purification As mentioned earlier, the existing flue gas desulfurization technology has the problems of energy waste and secondary pollution. The use of coupling system to realize the purification of SO2 and the utilization of coupling products is a new way to purify sulfur-containing flue gas. The co-production of H2 and H2O2 by anodizing SO2 significantly enhances the economy of flue gas desulfurization. In addition, coupled CO2 reduction also brings a new way to control the emission of CO2 in flue gas. 4.1 Simultaneous H2 generation and sulfate recovery SO2 converted to recyclable sulfate with synchronized H2 generation is resource-conserving method to purify SO2 compared to LSFO with its extra enormous limestones consumption. Besides, H2 is a simple, green energy source, which can be an alternative to fossil fuels [36]. The coupling system for H2 generation and sulfate recovery can store the energy released by SO2 oxidation in the generated H2 to reduce energy loss. Consequently, J. Han, et al. [19] reported a novel method for SO2 removal with simultaneously enhanced H2 generation by the PEC process using a nanoporous BiVO4 photoanode, whose mechanism is illustrated in Fig. 5a. In short, SO2 was absorbed by NaOH for the formation of Na2SO3, which was then oxidized on the photoanode, and H2 was generated on the cathode during the PEC process. In the case of pure NaOH(aq) as the electrolyte solution, the half reaction on the photoanode was (Eq. 18): (18) 2OH− → O2(g) + 2 H+ + 4e− E 0 = 1·23 V vs·RHE while in the existence of SO2 removal, the half reaction on the photoanode was (Eq. 19): (19) SO3 2− + 2OH− → SO4 2− + H2O + 2e− E 0 = 0·92 V vs·RHE Owing to the much lower activation energy and the fact that only 2e- was needed for the oxidation reaction of SO3 2−, the photogenerated holes would be easily and instantly consumed by Na2SO3, and a higher photocurrent was generated. However, for water oxidation, the reaction was much slower due to its higher activation energy and 4e- were required. Therefore, the photocurrent suffered from quick recombination of photogenerated charge carriers. Fig. 5b displayed the J-V curves of BiVO4 in the dark and under illumination in different concentrations of SO3 2-. In all cases, the removal rate of SO2 was found to be higher than 97 % under illumination. The current densities were negligible under dark conditions at applied biases lower than 0.5 V vs. Hg/HgO, indicating the effect of illumination on SO2 removal. The photocurrent densities increased with the addition of Na2SO3 (Fig. 5c). The above results indicated that Na2SO3 was directly responsible for the enhancement of photocurrent due to its low activation energy and fast kinetics as illustrated in Eqs.18,19, which was further verified by the more efficient charge transfer occurring at the electrode-solution interface for SO3 2- oxidation (Fig. 5d). In addition, the nanoporous BiVO4 showed much higher photocurrent response than the non-porous BiVO4 [84,85], because more holes reached the surface of the electrode with porous structure for much faster SO2 removal (Fig. 5e). The amounts of evolved H2 in different electrolyte solutions were measured at a bias of 1.6 V under AM 1.5 G irradiation (simulated solar light). In NaOH(aq) + SO2(g), a stable H2 evolution rate of 29.8 μmol h−1 cm−2 is obtained, which is 135 times faster than in NaOH(aq), implying that SO2 removal could dramatically increase H2 production. Moreover, the system demonstrated outstanding stability without any photocurrent decrease in the 3 h of the H2 production experiment. Table 1. One year later, another study [86] by the same authors increased the H2 generation rate from 29.8 μmol h−1 cm−2 to 60.26 μmol h−1 cm−2 via this PEC system achieved by using an improved Mo-doped BiVO4 inverse opals photoanode. Herein, authors utilized polystyrene spheres as template to assist Mo-doped BiVO4 in decorating FTO to synthesize IO-Bi(Mo)VO4 electrode. Synthesized IO-Bi(Mo)VO4 electrode possessed 3.42 mA cm−2 of current density, which was 5–6 times higher than no-Mo-doped BiVO4. And this work indicated approximately 10 L H2 could be synthesized by the proposed technique when 1 kWh electricity was generated by coal-burning power plant which could release around 0.03 kg SO2 [86] . Besides, the expense of ammonia-based desulfurization could decrease significantly and became profitable when combined with this H2 evolution process [86]. This work confirmed that the energy of SO3 2− wasted in conventional SO2 removal technology could be utilized in the process of solar-to-H2 energy conversion, which provided an alternative option when considering the removal of SO2 from flue gas. 4.2 Simultaneous HCOOH generation and sulfate recovery Actually, in addition to the clean energy like H2 generated synchronously by the cathode, it is also very meaningful to capture and convert CO2 into high value organic carbon like formic acid (HCOOH), among which both enormous amounts of CO2 and SO2 are urgently to be treated for air pollution control. In comparison to other organic carbon, HCOOH is a 2-electrons product of CO2 reduction that is obtained more favorably than other products more than 2 electrons [87–89] and faradaic efficiency of CO2-to-HCOOH could reach more than 98 % depended on catalytical technique [90]. Besides, HCOOH is more easily separated from flue gas as a liquid-state product and the hydrogenation reaction can consume enormous H+ to provide alkalinity for SO2 absorption. However, SO2 oxidation into sulfate is a useful method for sulfate recovery, and the energy released during the SO2 oxidation process could also be used to boost CO2 reduction. BiVO4 has recently become popular in photoelectrocatalysis due to its narrow band gap, which can effectively oxidize SO3 2- to SO4 2-. Besides, Cu-In bimetal was useful to overcome the issues such as low efficiency and poor selectivity in CO2 reduction. As is further studied, Li et al.[20] for the first time reported a photoelectrochemical (PEC) cell based on BiVO4 photoanode and Cu-In bimetallic cathode for HCOOH generation and SO2 removal simultaneously ( Fig. 6a). Meanwhile, the electrons were excited from the valence band (VB) to the conduction band (CB) and there were holes in the VB. The oxidation reaction of SO3 2- originated from SO2 occurred on the BiVO4/electrolyte interface, which consumed the holes and improved the separation of electron-hole pairs. Concurrently, the separated electrons would be transported to Cu-In bimetal cathode for HCOOH generation. In the current perspective, the electrode synthesized by Bi and Sn showed higher CO2-to-HCOOH selectivity, which was generally synthesized by hydrothermal process, electro-deposition, calcination processes or MOF (Metal Organic Framework) engineering. Besides, metallic oxide also worked greatly in this reaction, and the latest research suggests that it could reach higher than 95 % CO2-to-HCOOH selectivity. The electrode in this study still had plenty of room for improvement. The results showed the energy released from SO2 oxidation was reused, the densities were increased at least 3 times (Fig. 6c) and the internal resistance significantly descended (Fig. 6b). Furthermore, the oxidation efficiency (OE) of SO3 2- under different conditions was shown in Fig. 6d, demonstrating that the OE of the same anolytes improved with increased bias voltages due to higher electron-hole pair separation efficiency. The faradaic efficiency (FE) for the SO3 2- oxidation reaction clearly demonstrated a high SO3 2- removing selectivity, with FE greater than 90 % (Fig. 6e). Furthermore, the prepared Cu-In bimetal displayed better performance for HCOOH generation, possessing approximately 7.5 μmol h−1 HCOOH production rate during the CO2 reduction (Fig. 6f). 4.3 Simultaneous H2O2 generation and sulfate recovery SO2 removal combined with the production of H2O2 is a green chemistry coupling system that can generate high value-added energy while wastewater is treated. Accordingly, our group reported a novel two-compartment PEC coupling system based on bipolar membrane (BPM), which effectively realized sulfate recovery and H2O2 generation ( Fig. 7a) [21]. In general, the SO2 absorbed by the alkali liquor was rapidly converted to SO4 2− in the anode chamber, and the chemical energy released was effectively used by the cathode chamber to produce H2O2. The idea of the coupling system included three points: the optimal construction of an anode, cathode, and bipolar membrane. Hematite is a preferable alternative material for the anode due to its superior alkali corrosion resistance, long-term durability in alkaline solution [91], and strong photocorrosion resistance [92]. To improve the PEC performance of hematite, scientists have created a variety of preparation techniques, such as the conventional hydrothermal method [93–98], anodic and cathodic electrodeposition method [99–101], direct thermal treatment method [102], etc. In this work, a unique one-dimensional α-Fe2O3 nanorod film was grown on the FTO (Fig. 7b). The length and diameter of each nanorod were about 200 nm and 100 nm, which helped to guide electron transport and promote the separation of electron-hole pairs to enhance photocurrent. With the synergistic treatment of SO2, the photocurrent density of the system was increased by 40 % to 1.2 mA·cm−2 (Fig. 7c). For the cathode, GDE consisted of a special three-layer structure “Graphite + Nickel foam + Graphite” (Fig. 7d), with a hydrophobic porous structure. This structure allowed O2 to diffuse more rapidly to the reaction layer and provided enough active sites for the two-electron ORR process. Its Faradaic efficiency was much higher than that of the carbon-felt electrode and the Pt electrode (Fig. 7e). Furthermore, because of the distinct BPM, continuous hydrolysis produced OH- for SO2 adsorption and oxidization in the anodic chamber and H+ for O2 reduction and H2O2 evolution in the cathodic chamber. In this solar-driven coupled system, H2O2 evolution rate could reach 58.8 μmol L−1 h−1 cm−2 with the synergistic treatment of SO2, which was about five times more than that without SO2 (Fig. 7 f). With a series of constantly updating techniques, the proposed technology could also be used in practical coal-burning power plants to achieve economic and sustainable development. 5 Summary and outlook The construction of an electrochemical coupling system provides a waste treatment technique, that is simple in structure and operates efficiently at normal temperature and pressure. Based on the matching of matter and energy, the reduction reaction in the cathode and the oxidization reaction in the anode are successfully integrated. The coupling system constructed not only favorably accomplishes the removal and recycling of sulfur-containing gaseous waste, but also generates valuable H2, H2O2, CO2, etc., simultaneously. In the future, the development of electrochemical coupling system should focus on the following: (1) A photoelectric catalysis coupling system can significantly reduce external electricity requirements, but the performance of the system is limited by the energy conversion efficiency of semiconductor material. As for photoanode, light adsorption and charge transfer capacity are key factors to influence the performance of the designed electrode. Therefore, the performance of photoanode can be improved by a series of methods. Band gap engineering is an early approach to adjust the band gap structure of material to enhance charge transfer capacity, such as basic doping, defect engineering. After that, researchers set out to optimize microstructure of materials to strengthen internal light reflection and get more active sites. Then the appearance of heterojunctions and homojunctions can definitely improve light responsiveness and reduce the difficulty of separating h+-e- pairs, and the most prospective method may be the crystal facet engineering, which essentially change the property of the electrode material and have made some breakthroughs in photoelectric conversion. Moreover, the exploitation of high-performance semiconductor material such as perovskite, that possesses higher solar-to-electricity efficiency can further promote the energy efficiency of the coupling system. (2) Compared with photoelectric catalysis, electrocatalysis is more likely to be applied in practical industrialization, but the power efficiency problem is urgent to solve. We can continuously concentrate on the structure of electrochemical cell and the materials of the electrode. From the aspect of electrode materials, excellent conductivity and selectivity are of great importance to construct electrode. Metal catalysts are a beneficial choice for H2 generation, H2O2 evolution and CO2 reduction. For instance, Ni is suitable for H2O2 evolution and Co, Bi, Sn, etc., can assistant CO2 reduction to CO or HCOOH with high selectivity. Then nano engineering can provide more reaction sites by adjustment of microstructure of the materials. The most prospective approach is the introduction of GDE (gas diffusion electrode), which significantly enhance the participation of gases in reactions. On the other hand, an electrochemical flow cell is used to improve the efficiency of matter transmission and reduce internal resistance for much higher production rate. Overall, the use of electrochemical coupling systems to achieve synergistic treatment of various pollutants and resources through recycling has the potential to become a mainstream method of environmental protection and is important to the development of a sustainable and green society. coredata.dc:description: Sulfur-containing gaseous contaminant treatment is a key issue in the healthy and sustainable development of industry, especially SO2 and H2S occur with natural gas extraction and fossil fuel burning. Traditionally, the commercial method for H2S or SO2 requires numerous desiccants and enormous energy consumption. Encouragingly, electrochemical coupling system, which provide an efficient, sustainable, and economic pathway for sulfur-containing gaseous contaminants removal, can convert H2S and SO2 to recyclable substance in a moderate environment and simultaneously transfer the energy contained in them to other more valuable product. The current review discusses the mechanism and principle of the electrochemical coupling system as well as the recent studies on the electrochemical removal of H2S and SO2, with the goal of providing a suitable idea to solve the problems of energy waste and resource recovery in pollutants treatment.
coredata.dc:title: Electrochemical coupling conversion of sulfur-containing gaseous waste to treasure: A key review
